etymologies: mid 17th century: modern Latin, from Latin mille ‘thousand’, on the pattern of biennium

notes.text: The spelling of millennium is less difficult if one remembers that it comes ultimately from two Latin words containing double letters: mille, ‘thousand,’ and annum, ‘year.’

definitions: a period of a thousand years, especially when calculated from the traditional date of the birth of Christ

examples.text: silver first came into use on a substantial scale during the 3rd millennium BC

definitions: the prophesied thousand-year reign of Christ at the end of the age (Rev. 20:1–5)

examples.text: Archer's treatise predicted that the millennium was close at hand

shortDefinitions: prophesied thousand-year reign of Christ at end of age

definitions: a utopian period of good government, great happiness, and prosperity

examples.text: the people must seize power—the millennium cannot be imposed on them from above

shortDefinitions: utopian period of justice and prosperity

definitions: an anniversary of a thousand years

examples.text: the millennium of the Russian Orthodox Church

definitions: the point at which one period of a thousand years ends and another begins

examples.text: as we approach the millennium the only certainty is change

shortDefinitions: point at which one period of thousand years ends and another begins
